column1: Before 18 July 2020, will President Trump announce that Nikki Haley will be his 2020 running mate?
column6: ['US Politics', 'Elections and Referenda']
Not going to happen.
It does not happen without milking the process for political gains
very unlikely given short timeframe remaining
Mike Pence.
it is a very specific event within what is now a very small timeframe. don't know anything about this from a political strategy perspective but odds for this specific event seem small.

Pence helped Trump consolidate the evangelical vote in 2016. That job is done and evangelicals won't leave Trump any under reasonable scenario. If Trump is behind and feels the need to throw a hail mary, then Nikki Haley is his target in the endzone. For all his faults, Trump gets strategy, to a fault. Nikki Haley as VP is a good strategy in a comeback scenario.
No sign or indication of a change.
An older article (https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/03/politics/nikki-haley-mike-pence-trump-vp/index.html), read in our current context, has some counter-reasoning that now seems flimsy.
Six months ago, I would have this at 40%. By end of March, over 50%. But now, with such fragile support for Trump, something needs to happen. This isn't it however.
Almost out of time. FYI https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jul/10/nikki-haley-post-trump-republican-party

While I think it's highly unlikely, I think Trump is getting increasingly desperate and his behavior more and more erratic, so doing something drastic like this wouldn't surprise me—especially since he doesn't seem to take advice from much of anyone.
Nikki Haley is a great conservative pick for V.P. , but Pence has been a tried and true supporter of the president. If Pence wants more family time and out of the fray, he may not mind stepping out.

Timeline.

I still think she has a high degree of likelihood for replacing Pence, but I would suspect Trump would do it in August, on the last day of the dem convention, as phrased by the question. Less likely to see it happen during the next 2 weeks.

I'm changing down, again. But not because I think Trump wouldn't throw Pence aside if he thought it might help. I DO think he'll do something bold like this, right in the middle or at the end of the Dem convention. But now I'm thinking Elise Stefanik might be the more likely one than Haley. He's bringing her along on a lot of events these days. I fully expect Trump is considering placing all covid blame on Pence. Trump is hurting badly among suburban women. He's got the evangelical crowd locked up already, regardless of all evidence that should be to the contrary.

I am increasing my forecast. Once Biden names a female VP, DT might think it would help his Lagging polling numbers if he also had a female on the Ticket. She is the only one on the radar. Plus, DT is big with the blame game and throwing others under the bus. So his move to put Pence Officially in charge of the pandemic crisis makes him the perfect scapegoat. Bolton’s new book has some scathing remarks about her, but one of those remarks is her desire to move up the political ladder.
Updating, Very unlikely now there will be a change bu t not impossible if poll numbers remain poor and he thinks a change will turn things around.

We now have confirmation that Trump has actively considered swapping Pence for Haley: "Former National Security Adviser John Bolton mercilessly criticizes President Donald Trump in his new book but writes that he had a White House ally in the vice president ... Bolton argued for keeping Pence on the 2020 ticket when Trump asked if he should replace him with Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador." https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/06/21/john-bolton-book-describes-vice-president-mike-pence-alley/3232696001/

You know, I'm going to take a bold stab at this being far more possible than anyone would expect. Trump has 0% loyalty to anyone when they cease being useful to him. He could very easily blame Pence for the entire covid response, and I fully expect he will, if he feels it's necessary. It would certainly shake things up, and make for good tv. He also likes to distract and get news attention when it's needed, so I think this would actually be a genius move. Especially when Biden doesn't have the enthusiastic support that he was hoping for, it would suck the wind out of the news cycle for Biden, which would be the point. She remains oddly loyal to Trump it seems.
Mike Pence will be running mate barring his death or incapacity.

I think Pence is necessary for his evangelical base and the other good chunk of his base seems to be right wing extremist. I don’t think he would get away with that for a running mate. He is losing white, suburban women voters in droves - so there is a chance he would grasp at that Haley straw if it brought them back. (Doubtful)
(no change, still think it might be Pompeo) If this approach doesn't work:
He'll never pick a woman. And Pence is actively sucking up to him.

Thinking about this some. While she often supports Trump she has her own differing ideas. She is already high profile and does not need VP position for that. She probably would not accept an offer. Next would he offer her the position. It might help him with suburban women. It would raise her chances of the nomination in 2024 though. Trump would rather elevate one of his children for that role. Ivanka 2024 has already been seen on his bus. Lowering.

But otherwise unlikely, and no guarantee he'll pick Haley. And I do not buy reports that anybody knows what Trump will do, I think the only certainty is that he's unpredictable.

Down 10% to be below the consensus. I still believe it likely that DT will dump Pence, but I deluded myself that Haley would be the replacement. Pompeo is my guess now. This explains the lame brain IG firing before there was an official slap. And why worry about morale or mission if one is headed to greater things? The DT base will be fired up with two aggrieved figureheads. He'd be a better debater, has ties to evangelicals, and obviously the 2.0 would do a much better job managing the next crisis.

Let's say the odds that Trump gets rid of Pence sometime before election are 25%. Would seem odd to me if he dumped him after Pence has been in the national spotlight with the coronavirus task force. Even if Trump needs to pick a replacement VP, odds aren't 100% that he'll pick Haley. I'd say 50% or so. So odds of both of the above happening are 13%.

Given the amount of responsibility that President Trump has given Mike Pence(the Coronavirus Task Force, the National Space Council), and that there are several issues with which Nikki Haley is at odds with Trump's base, it's very unlikely that he will change his plan to make someone who hasn't been introduced to the national public. Mike Pence has been in public consciousness for a long while now, and switching out a team member like that is unlike Trump, as he has tended to reward those who are loyal to him.

A quick check shows since 1988 shows presidential candidates are about 50/50 on whether they announce the VP pick in July vs August. There are no examples of going back to 1980 of a president picking a diff VP for second term. So I'm assigning a black box guess of 25% the random chance the Pence is not chosen. And last for Haley to be picked as a VP over any other potential choice I will also black box at 25%. So .50 x .25 x .25 = .03125

It's unusual for US president's to switch running mate, and while Trump may choose to jettison Pence (say 50% chance), and may choose to pick a woman to counter Biden's commitment (say conditional probability of 80%), there are a lot of women in this country. Haley is not from a swing state (SC) and that won't help her position. But she is the rumor-mill favorite.

It's unusual for US president's to switch running mate, and while Trump may choose to jettison Pence (say 50% chance), and may choose to pick a woman to counter Biden's commitment (say 70%), there are a lot of women in this country. Haley isn't from a swing state and that will count against her.

While not probable, it is a possibility. Incumbent presidents have chosen a new VP candidate 11 times in U.S. history. While this hasn't happened in approx. 100 years, it would fit Trump's character to drop his running mate in favor of someone that he thinks may give him an advantage. Especially since Biden says that he will choose a female running mate, Trump could choose one as well to counter Biden.

In the modern presidential era, no candidate has ever switched their VP. So we begin with 99-1. However, Trump is unconventional and by placing Pence in charge of the COVID-19 response he may be setting up a scenario where he blames Pence and switches him out for Nikki Haley. However this scenario has low probability and strikes me as a hail mary if the COVID-19 response goes poorly.

Vice-president Pence is now the coronavirus Czar, but don't really have a full media presence because of President Trump daily press conference. If things go wrong probably will see vice-president Pence in prime time trying to cotain the debacle and eventually discarded for mistakes. If President Trump is still on first time on media vice-president Pence is not guilty.

Mike Pence is doing fine. No reason for trump to dump him.
I believe she'd rather run for the top job in 2024.
since first forecast, the pandemic as changed the political landscape and now is not the time to go long on changes

Although I do see where Begala is coming from, I just don't see this happening. The reason that I am giving a percentage here as high as 10% is simply because of Trump's showmanship- he is known to love a good plot twist, and theoretically it could be a smart political move to try and sway middle-ground women in favor of the Republican ticket now should it include a woman as Vice President. This may be even more probable since Begala made his claim on March 2, as Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, promised to name a woman as his running mate in a debate with Bernie Sanders on March 15, so Trump could use this as a tactic to match Biden and block him from using the "female VP" card to his advantage. However, despite all this, it still seems highly improbable that this will actually happen. For one, current VP Mike Pence is a very "stable" candidate, contrary to Trump's colorful personality that many traditional GOP members dislike, and who has already proven himself capable of the position. Additionally, a change in running mate when running for reelection has only been done three times in U.S. history, and the most recent instance was when President Franklin D. Roosevelt ran for an unprecedented third term with a new running mate in 1940. Many Americans, Democrat and Republican alike, agree that Pence has been a very capable leader in his position at the head of the COVID-19 response task force, and he has a strong favorability rating among most Republicans, making him a reliable partner. Even if Trump does decide to dump Pence, there is no guarantee that he would replace him with Haley, or even if Haley would accept the position. This seems like an idea that might sound okay on paper, but in all likelihood will not work out in practice, if it is even attempted at all.

It seems doubtful, especially given the Covid-19 outbreak, that Trump would announce a new running mate at this time. The focus of the administration and its reelection concerns at the moment is far more focused on ensuring that the economy does not enter a long term recession or face a financial meltdown. Additionally, it will be unclear how the administration will need to increase its support amongst voters until after the Democratic national Convention, anticipated to be in July. The Covid=19 pandemic will likely push this back past. the July 18th timeframe.
Paul Begala who said it was "a certainty," just wanted attention and overstated his confidence. Pence will be very hard to get rid of after the competent job he does with the coronavirus response.
Following the economic collapse, with Pence in charge of "fixing" coronavirus, POTUS will use the opportunity to make this change. It will be an attempt to offset Biden having a female VP
It's not impossible -- that's the best I can say for it.
He has no need to change with Pence
Revising down from previous forecast on chance Haley says no for her own reasons. My reasoning otherwise still stands.
This has not happened since 1976,

The coronavirus right now is taking its toll on the economy and over time will take a toll on Trump's popularity, despite the recent slight bump up. Trump asking Nikki Haley to run is very likely. However, I really doubt Nikki Haley will want to be associated with Trump during this period. It could ruin her chances of running for president or senator in the future. Also, vice presidents of failed presidential nominees, even incumbents, historically do not do well afterward.
His tongue isn't long enough
Pence to be tested, not making Haley more likely, but making the prospect more relevant: https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/488808-pence-says-he-will-be-tested-for-coronavirus
Not sure it’s the right person. But we have to see if Trump gets sick first. Virus will delay most things. Also if Pence does good job with pandemic then it would be hard to drop him.
Nikky Haley resigning from the Boeing board indicates her independence.
Only if Pence dies
Upgrading slightly due to putting Pence in charge of coronavirus response (which will turn bad).

Trump has confirmed Pence as his VP already for 2020. Begala's argument that Haley would draw votes from "suburban moms" means little, considering the sheer number of white women ages 25-40 Trump/Pence drew during the 2016 election. There is little to be gained from a switch in VP this late in the game, especially considering how soon Trump's 2020 campaign began--the day of his inauguration in 2017. Logistically, it's enough work that no one would advise it. However, this does not rule out the likelihood of Trump making a spur of the moment decision, which is why I am not going for an absolute zero here. Anything is possible. Unfortunately.

I think President Trump will name Niiki Haley as his VP pick on two conditions: 1. if coronavirus response is not going well (lack of public confidence) then President Trump will fault VP Pence and choose a new running mate and 2. If Biden has chosen a female running mate

Highly unlikely. While Pence is far less important to the ticket in '20 than he was in '16 (reassuring social and evangelical conservatives that they can vote for a New Yorker with a history of liberal social issue stances, who spent considerable time in his life as a Democrat), Trump and Pence now have fairly similar favorability numbers and approvals. It wouldn't make much of a difference as voters don't vote based on the bottom of the ticket for the most part. The GOP also might want to avoid the association of their next nominee (another prediction) with Trump and see Haley is a viable bridge candidate between the new GOP or the Trump GOP and the old GOP. Far more likely is the odds Nikki Haley runs in 2024 (95%), wins the nomination (40%, plurality leader in a crowded field), and becomes the first female U.S. President (65% in a one-on-one matchup, but overall: .95 x .4 x.65).
if this is happening, doubt it's own this timeline due to corona.
Nikki Haley looks good, and the femaler/ethicity thing works for her. But there are lots of other possibilities
She's the best choice, but Trump might feel that he wants to stick with Pence, who is a loyal yes man.
Trump needs the evangelical base that Pence represents. Evangelicals will never accept a woman President.

It is very unlikely for Trump to change his VP, especially to a woman. 1. Biden will have a female running mate. Trump will not allow himself to follow Biden's lead in choosing a woman. 2. There is no need for Trump to pick a woman running mate - unlike Biden, his constituents do not demand it. 3. If offer, Haley is likely to decline. The common view is that Trump will lose in the next election. There is no reason for her to join a losing team - how many losing VP candidates can you remember? She is likely to go into a presidential run, but she can wait after the election.
Trump will be advised to wait until he has no choice but to announce his running mate. If he decides to go with Haley, he will wait until what he thinks is the ideal moment.

Higher than I would normally put, but if there needs to be a scapegoat for the COVID-19 epidemic Trump could use Pence's position as the head of the task force as a reason to distance himself from this.
Given the pandemic, he's unlikely to make decisions about the election until closer to November
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2020/02/20/haley_taps_key_conservative_fueling_2024_speculation.html https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/03/politics/nikki-haley-mike-pence-trump-vp/index.html
Pence will pardon TRUMP after election. for federal crimes.

Outside view/Base rate: Incumbent presidents who switched VPs when running for second term: 5 [1,2] - 1864: Lincoln switching from Hamlin to Johnson - 1872: Grant switching from Colfax to Wilson - 1892: Harrison switching from Morton to Reid - 1944: Roosevelt switching from Wallace to Truman - 1976: Ford switching from Rockefeller to Dole * Not counting VP Garner challenging Roosevelt in 1940, forcing Roosevelt to choose Wallace as a new running mate. Or Agnew resigning under Nixon, causing Nixon to pick a new running mate. Or VPs dying during first term, causing president to pick new running mate. * Also starting since Civil War given "historically, presidential nominees had little role in choosing who their running mate was. Party leaders made the choice, with ticket-balancing usually the chief concern. As a result, presidents and vice presidents frequently had little to do with one another, with vice presidents frequently accorded no role at all in the administration." [3]
Winning is the goal.I believe you need a woman on the ticket to entice woman voters.
Biden will pick VP on July 16, so Trump will try to upstage the Democrats and pick a woman.
She will try to stay close enough to Trump to get support from his base but distant enough to have a broader appeal. Tough line to walk.

I originally gave this a 5% chance, to convey that it's technically possible, but I'd say even that was an overestimate. I think my mind is being narrowed a bit by the current Coronavirus pandemic, but it's something that a _CNN_ contributor said and I just don't think Trump would let them be right about something. I'm leaving a couple of percentage points because I don't know enough about the current state of the White House (he could really really want Haley, and 1 in 50 seems like a reasonable probability for that).
Nikki is an airhead albeit an ambitious one. She adds nothing to the ticket. She is not all that trustworthy and has gone against Trump before.

Slicing my recent forecast in half, owing to the realization that *if* Trump replaces Pence, Nikki Haley is only one option Trump might go with. On a gut-level feeling, I've experienced Trump as not likely to follow through with what is being expected of him.
Down 40% for passage of time to be closer to the consensus.

The primary issue the time frame. Right now Pence is getting a lot of public attention as Trump's designee to handle the coronavirus. Pence is therefore deflecting some of the negative publicity. I suspect most people think this makes him less likely to be replaced as VP because he willingly served as a lighting rod protecting the president. I disagree. If Pence is perceived as someone who did a very good job for the country prior the election Trump will both keep him and demand credit for all Pence's good works. However, I also believe that if Pence becomes unpopular due to his handling of the coronavirus, which I think is much more likely, then Trump will not care about how much Pence has done for him and dump him.
If he replaces Pence, he is admitting that his response to the COV-19 virus has failed.

21 presidents have served more than 1 term. There have been 4 instances of Vice President swaps for a second term (twice with FDR). Base rate is ~14%. Since 1899, there have been 4 changes in VP under the same President. 1 was by death, 1 by resignation from prior scandal, 1 by a decision to run against his boss and 1 by internal party opposition during the campaign. If I take scandal as the most similar case, I get a base rate of about 1/24, which I round down to 3-4%. Trump's volatility as a employer is negated, I think, by the fact that he's found nothing negative to say about Pence yet. I also don't expect the Corona crisis to rise to an unbearable pitch by May/June, as I've seen reports suggesting it will have larger effects in winter months, so the possibility of a scandal also seems very low. Even if he wants to drop Pence, Nicki Haley may not be eager for the position.

Since turn of 20th century only one president switched from their initial vp choice. This is a little over 7%. Trump is unconventional and has been known to fire cabinet members with some frequency so I added 2%. I cut that by 2/3 for much the same reason.

45 presidents, but 5 chose not to run, so 40 presidents running for re-election. 9 of them had different vice presidents, putting a base rate at 22.5% (9/40). Gave a slight bump based on current presidential behavior and a 2018 article saying she was a front runner. Would give a higher bump, but media also predicted Clinton would replace Biden on Obama's reelection ticket.

Since 1900 only one incumbent president has changed their VP (that picked their VP the first time), FDR who did it twice picking Truman in 1944 and Wallace in 1940. All other presidents kept their VP, which total 12 elections between 1900 and 2012. This gives a base rate of 2/14 = 14%. I'd suggest that more recent observations are more pertinent and so a more reasonable base rate is around 5-10%.
